transcript.transcript: Okay. Today is May 3rd, 2007, and this is going to be an oral history interview with Doctor Harold Morowitz, who is Robinson Professor at George Mason University. And we are going to focus on his affiliation with the Santa Fe Institute. And conducting the interview will be Veronica Fletcher and Katia Herring. And behind the camera is Dave. Okay, so first of all, thank you very much for agreeing to do this. It's a pleasure to have a chance to talk with you about the Santa Fe Institute, and also about the connection between the Santa Fe Institute and the Krasnow Institute. Um, so can you just tell us when and how did you learn about the plans to establish the Santa Fe Institute? 1987? Uh, I was involved in running a or setting up to run a summer workshop on computers and biology, and I don't think such a workshop had ever been run before. That is way before bioinformatics existed. And we were looking for a institution to a place to actually run it. We needed classrooms and dormitories and so forth and so on. And we went around trying various places we knew. And a lot of colleges and universities have such facilities. And they all had overhead rates that were going to drain our budget. So we couldn't run the the conference or the workshop. And Santa Fe Institute had just gotten established. And someone and I'm not even sure now who was on the committee, which was setting up for the summer conference, told me about the Santa Fe Institute being set up. And he said he thought that we could run a the conference through them and we could hold it at Saint John's College in Santa Fe And that meant, uh, we would have a place to house the students. They were occasionally put up summer workshops and meetings and so forth. And he said they're just getting established. And they would probably really like to do this. And you can probably negotiate about overhead. The, uh, give you some insight as to things that underlie where these things happen. Uh, in any case, I got in touch with, uh, uh, Doctor George Cowan, who was the president of the Santa Fe Institute. And they had just been established, I believe, for two years or a year and a half at that time. And he said, yes, they would be glad to sponsor such an event. And, uh, he would he would see that we got over the overhead problems so that we could have the have the meeting out there. He said if push came to shove, I just had to provide for ginger salary. I know you've interviewed Ginger, so. So anyway, I went out there and conferred with George Cowan and Ginger, and we put the whole thing together rather rapidly so that this, uh, it was a six week summer workshop held at, uh, at Saint John's College under the auspices of the Santa Fe Institute. And, uh, it involved, uh, we had about eight on the faculty with some turnover of people coming and going on the faculty. And then we had about 15 to 20 students who are largely graduate students and post-doctoral, and a few faculty members from various places around the country. And as I say, this was the first real workshop that had ever been run in the subject and that, uh, that led to real enthusiasm on the part of the people who came. They had all been at their own institutions trying to get this going, and suddenly to be with, uh, 20 to 30 other people who were interested in the same thing, really. It was it was in a way, the time and place were right. Everything just worked. And, uh, and, uh, so we, we had the workshop there for, for, for six weeks and the other people heard about it. People began to come from around the country. A graduate student came from Stanford for two days and he stayed for three weeks. And it was, uh, it may be a little hard to visualize now when things seem to be very highly organized, but we were able to put it together in a rather informal way. And in the chemistry lab at Saint John's, we set up a bunch of computers, which we got on loan from IBM. We didn't have much money for this. We had to scrounge. And, uh, by the end of the six weeks, the biologists were all sitting at computers and the computer people were all poring over biochemistry books. And it all came together in a very nice way. Uh, the other person who ran this with me jointly was Temple Smith, who's now at Boston University, and he's professor, I believe, of computer science or bioinformatics. He's in this field. So he and I were jointly responsible for signing it up and and getting it going. And, uh, I don't know how much you want to know about it. Yeah. Tell us about you. Want you want more details? Uh, basically, we would meet every morning and we'd have a series of lectures, and then we broke up into four groups in the afternoon. People who were, uh, had specific problems. One was working on the bio bio, the what computers could do with biochemical networks, and another was interested in ecology and various, uh, special topics. So the, uh, as I say, we would meet together for 2 or 3 hours in the morning, and then each of these groups would work over the afternoon. Uh, Saint John's College is a sort of funny place for a, uh, for carving out the future. Because when I went to the library, there were the great books are the education, the for the last 2500 years. So I began to think about what Aristotle and such people would have thought of, what we were, what we were doing. I decided that Aristotle would have liked it. Plato wouldn't have been happy. But. Uh. Why not? Oh, well, because Aristotle was really tied up with databases. That is, he was involved in this book on Animalia is putting together everything that was then known about animals. And he's got another one on plants and so forth. And, uh, and Plato was more concerned with his abstract absolutes and so forth, and I think he would have been less impressed with our computers being able to get a lot of information out of databases. Uh, anyway, the, uh, the people who were there then did go on to become kind of the the core of bioinformatics in the United States. Uh, there was a young man named Bruce Schatz who was working in a telephone company in new Jersey, but was interested in, uh, how you could use computers to extract maximum amount of material from the Electric chair, he went on. He's now a professor at the University of Illinois, runs a large bioinformatics group in Champaign-Urbana. There was a young graduate student who came from Stanford, Peter Karp. And after this, he completed his thesis. And he stayed at the Stanford Research Institute, where he now runs a very large biological database called Metacyc. And, uh, I mean, I if I had the list, I could go through all the people, but it was I give you some of the superstars, but but again, a lot of those people went on to kind of become something of the core of bioinformatics in the United States. And uh, and interesting things kept happening because it was the Santa Fe Institute and they were getting started. They wanted to show it off. And one day, Doctor Cowan showed up with Senator Domenici, who was the senator from New Mexico. And he wanted to show him what we were doing out there. And another day he showed up with the governor of New Mexico. So that, uh, it was it was just one of those not totally planned things that all turned out to the good. And so, uh, it went on for, for six weeks, but then a lot of the. Uh, a lot of the people who worked on this, uh, stayed in the field and kept their contacts with each other. And so it was the it was, I mean, Computers in biology would have happened anyway, but this was an event which got a lot, of lot of things going. Uh, while out in Santa Fe, uh, I got to meet several of the people who were at the Institute, and lo and behold, uh, there at the institute was, uh, Murray Gell-Mann, uh, who you may know as having won the Nobel Prize for the discovery of the quark. I knew him as my lab partner in sophomore physics, and it was nice to reestablish our acquaintance. And, uh, and I met a number of other people at, at the, at at the institute. And, uh, so that went for the that that was the summer. And so about the other people at the Institute. Had you known or cooperated with Doctor Cowan before? No, I did not know Doctor Cowan at all. I, I, I phoned him up to ask him about having a meeting at out there. That was the first. We immediately hit it off of course. So since you mentioned Murray Gell-Mann, can you just tell us a little more about your relationship with him and how you. Oh, okay. We were both undergraduates together in Yale. At Yale. Uh, I was class of 47. He was class of 48. And, uh, we were, uh, we were both majoring in physics, although, uh, before, uh, the, uh, before I left, I had switched my major to an undergraduate major in philosophy and physics at Murray, of course, went on to graduate in physics, and he went on to MIT, where he got his PhD and then went on to a Nobel Prize for the discovery of the quark. And so we hadn't seen each other much during the intervening time I had been on the East Coast, he had been on the West Coast. We had encountered occasionally a meeting, but we didn't usually go to the same meetings, because by that time my interest had shifted into biology and he was into particle physics. So that was the. So it was nice to to join up again. And then now, of course, I go out there with some frequency. So we see each other about once a year or are frequently very nice. And so then after the conference took place in 1987. And how did your relationship with the Santa Fe Institute develop? I'm having a hard time remembering that, to tell you the truth, I. I kept in touch with with some of the people and, uh. I the dates I don't have clearly outline, but I decided that it would be a good idea to go out for a few months for my next sabbatical to spend some time out at the institute. And, uh, So sometime in the, I guess, about, uh. 1989, uh, probably I went out and, uh, spent some time at the institute. The institute then was largely dominated by physics and physicists, although there was some work getting started in economics. And there were, uh, there were other subjects that what people were seeing was that the techniques, I think, largely driven by computers, uh, uh, established common features for all complex systems where you could sort of deal with them in a in a related way, uh, regardless of the field you were in when you tried to put it in mathematical form, you would encounter some of the same equations, and the techniques for solving them tended to spread across the, uh, the fields and the the founders of the institute, Cowan and Gilman and, uh, that early group, which were people who I think largely knew each other through Los Alamos in the first instance. I think that's what I think. That's where the basic ideas came from. And Cowan was, of course, a very senior person at, at Los Alamos. And, uh, so I think that group, largely coming out of physics, had become convinced that the techniques, Uh, that were being applied to complex systems in physics, where generally applicable into in all sorts of fields. And uh, sometime back in the early days, I think largely at the instigation of Philip Anderson, who was at Bell Labs and he's now at Princeton, uh, it was a physicist, but had become interested in economics. And he ran a big meeting on, uh, applying complex systems method to economics. Uh, Brian Arthur came out there from Stanford, and this really became his full time work. And he moved from Stanford to spend full time at the Santa Fe Institute. And there were a number of other people in that, in that, in that economics group that were involved in getting things set up and started. And then the idea was largely established of having these meetings looking at complexity in various areas. And this led to a series of, uh, of, of books on these conferences in, uh. In various areas of complexity. I think there's now about 30 or 40 of them have been put out. So that's a anyone who's interested in real detail about what was going on at these meetings. And these meetings would gather people in different fields from, uh, Largely from the United States, but also from other parts of the world, to try and explore new ideas. And so some, uh, a number of fields kind of got started at these meetings. Okay. Yeah. We'll address in a little while. Also the one joint conference or the conference with the Krasnow Institute. Right. But yeah, before we get there, um, at one point, you became the head of the the chair of the science board at the Santa Fe Institute. Right? Yeah, that's much later. That's much later. Okay. That I think I think I chaired the board from 1982 to 96. Excuse me. I'm not that old. From 2002 to 2006. Okay. Okay. And so, as chair of the science board, what were your tasks? The, uh. Science board, uh, largely its function is largely to meet once a year and, uh, to listen to what's going on at the institute. And then from a point of view of the various expertise, there's a real attempt to make made to get people on the science board and all sorts of conceivable subjects that are related to this theme of complexity. I don't know if I've stressed it enough, but the central theme of complexity is what all this, uh, hinges on. And so the board would meet once a year. And, uh, and we've, we've tried different things. Two years ago, we had some members of the board actually give talks themselves on what was going on new in their particular field that might be of interest to the people at the Institute. The year before that was mainly people at the institute talking about their work and giving people on the board a chance to comment on it. So it's a it's not really an operational group to science board. It's an advisory group to tie the Santa Fe Institute into the science community, again, largely United States. But science has become so international now that it it's hard to distinguish between whether it's just the United States or the world. So and that brought together a group of Really distinguished people. I remember, I think the first meeting of the board I went to back. Back maybe 1990. Somewhere around that, it was sitting around the table with 30 people, including 3 or 4 Nobel laureates and so forth and so on. It was pretty impressive. And, uh, that group did bring together some of the most distinguished scientists in the world who were interested specifically in these more theoretical and mathematical approaches. The institute has never had an experimental division, although a lot of what goes on in the institute, people take the ideas and go back and work with them experimentally in various places. But but that was the. That was the main. Anyway, the main function of the science board is advisory to the to the staff at the Institute. And what's happened of course, over the years, the the institute consists of the in-house faculty and the staff and then people who are external, external professors who come anywheres from a week to six months to a year to work at the institute. So, uh, that, as I say, is a group that's sort of grown over the years. That was probably at the beginning, a cluster of maybe 10 or 12 people. And now it's probably a cluster of 40 or 50 people. So there's been that that kind of growth taking place, including a a postdoctoral fellowship program. We're actually funds are available for people to come in around 2 or 3 years to to work with people at the institute. And uh, and then the in summer there's an undergraduate program, and then there are programs involving interaction with, with local schools to do some outreach on modern science. And so it has really moved in a lot of directions. Um, so as we're talking about the growth, could you just sort of comment and outline the growth of the Santa Fe Institute during the last 20 years that you've been affiliated with it? Well, as I say it physically, let me describe it physically first. That's kind of interesting. It was a when I first came there. The the institute had rented a convent from the Diocese of Santa Fe, uh, which was, uh, I think, no longer in use as a convent because I think the, uh, the school where the sisters used to teach, uh, uh, there were fewer religious teaching in the school and more laity teachers so that there just was not that population of religious women. So the convent's original use was no longer. And, uh, so the, uh, I don't know who arranged this. Probably Jorge Coulon arranged to rent it from the diocese, and, uh. So for the first 3 or 4 years, that's that's where the institute was housed. And then, uh, the diocese wanted the building back because they had some other plans for it. And the institute moved to law offices. They rented, I think it I think it probably had been two suites of law offices, two adjacent suites of law offices. And they were there for about. I guess 4 or 5 years. And during that time they were, uh, trying to raise funds and planning on buying a permanent site. And, uh, again, I haven't kept quite track of the years in which this happened, but probably ten years ago. Anyway, this. This site on Hyde Park Road, which had been the house of I believe it was General Hurley. Not totally sure of his name. He had been a United States Representative to China during World War two. And when he returned, he was going to run for senator from New Mexico. And he bought this big house. I don't know if he ever ran for Senator, I, I didn't follow that. But there's a history of the House. If you're doing an oral history thing, you might want to you might find it interesting to check out. Anyway, the institute finally was able to raise enough funds, and in this time there had been another growing group, which were the board of trustees, and they consisted of among the scientists, but also a group of people, largely from high tech business people, from computers, communications, uh, uh, a large group of people who, coming from that field of business, could, could see the mission of the Institute. It it resonated with what they thought about where progress was going to be made. So they, uh, they supported it and, uh, and raised enough money to buy this property. And then the house had to be, uh, well, it was first, uh, renovated and then, a couple of years later, a large wing was added to it. So now, as I say, depending on the time of year, probably houses between 40 to 70 people more in summer. Mhm. Um, so and what would you say were the most interesting projects that you have worked with, been affiliated with at the Santa Fe Institute over the years? Actually they have been largely in the past four years. And not that the others weren't interesting, but, uh, about four years ago, I began to work with Eric Smith, who's a member of the faculty. And Eric is a physicist who is. Interested in the kind of basic principles of biology, which is something I had been working on my whole career, but I had been working on it from a top down level to take the generalizations from from all of biology and to see if there were core generalizations that that would tell us what were the principles by which biological systems work. Eric, who I didn't know at the time, had come as a postdoc to the institute and was working as a physicist from the bottom up, from the physics of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics to see if there were principles of biology. And when we met, it was sort of a natural collaboration, which has gone on now for 4 or 5 years, I guess. Yeah. And it has turned out to be, uh. It's been very, very fruitful. We've been joined, uh, we have a third collaborator who's a chemist from the University of Colorado. So the three of us worked there together in the summers. And that, uh, that collaboration has been, uh, it brought it brought some very diverse things together with a group of people who were struggling to communicate with each other across these disciplinary. And in a way, that's the secret of the Santa Fe Institute that, uh, a cross-disciplinary is used, uh, in a lot of places, but it's used kind of as a code word. But here it's really taken seriously. At the Institute. It's really taken seriously. Yeah. So as you mentioned, the cross-disciplinary. And collaboration. So what would you say were the major accomplishments of the Santa Fe Institute? Over the years? The Institute as a whole. As a. Yeah, as a place. Uh, I think they have transformed. The theoretical approaches that were core to the physical sciences, the theoretical and mathematical process of physical sciences. They transform them so that they could be applied to the biological sciences and to the social sciences like economics. They've done modeling and archaeology. It's taking those powerful mathematical techniques instantly, all of which were possible to apply in those other areas because of the development of computers. And that's a very important part of it. I don't think any of this would have happened without the parallel, large scale development of computers. So it's been able to take those principles, which had been confined to the physical sciences and make them available as, as theoretical approaches, uh, uh, across a wide field of, of disciplines. I would say that that marks the, uh, the feature of the Institute, the principal most important feature of the institute. And what would you say? Where and are the major challenges for the Santa Fe Institute to, you know, continue to work along these lines? What are the challenges? I don't think I'm going to be a seer because I don't think, you know, I mean, I think you get I think you get very good people who are very interested in what they're doing, working at these things. And, I mean, how would I know that when I went out there to a summer to work five years ago, I would meet this physicist who's working at the same problem or a different point of view, just mesh so that we had a new way of looking at things. And that's sort of unpredictable. Okay. Okay, good. So maybe we should move on to. George Mason University. Okay. And if you would discuss the relationship between the Santa Fe Institute and the Krasnow Institute. Okay. Uh. There. We don't have a formal relationship. It is all, uh, uh, involving people who know each other and work together and so forth. When the, uh, Krasnow Institute was being established, uh, around early 1990s, uh, we, uh. President Johnson was looking for a focus for for the institute. Money had been left in an estate by Shelly Krasnow, and he said it was for an institute for advanced study for the benefit of mankind. And unfortunately, he died before he spelled it out any further. And so President Johnson and Mark Friedlander, who was the head of the board of directors of the institute, were looking for what field to work at. So a group of us suggested bringing in a group of wise people from around the world. To, uh, to get a subject matter to focus on for a mission for the Institute. So we invited about 12 people, 4 or 5 of them were Nobel laureates. And, uh, they. know. They came and were interviewed by the board of directors of the Krasnow and President Johnson and, uh, they, uh, after all of those had been put together, uh, somehow, uh, again, Mary Gelman was one of those who was fairly influential talking about complex systems. And, uh, the by the time all those people had been been listened to and so forth, it looked like there was an area, uh, which we called the mind, the brain and complex systems. And we didn't have that as well-defined then as we do now. I mean, now what it has come to? Well, it always was, but we've come to focus on it a little more tightly. It's the intersection between neurobiology, cognitive psychology and computational neurosciences. It's where the three of those come together. And in fact, this year we're running a conference which is to trigger off something called the decade of the mind, which is an extent to take what's been developed in the last 20 years and so forth, and see how this can be now extended to a firmer understanding of the nature of the mind, which is still one of the one of the real puzzles of science. So when, when we decided that that we this is before we had to building the institute and so forth, but we decided that was going to be the subject matter. We decided to run a big conference on the mind, the brain and complex systems. So we invited a dozen really superstars to come speak and had a three day meeting here. Uh, and it, uh, we had an audience of about 500 at the Harris Theater. Whatever fills the theater. But we filled the theater. Uh, and, uh, that that sort of, uh, but in setting that up, I was in close contact with several people at the Santa Fe Institute who had a lot of experience in setting up and running big meetings like that. And then as a result, We decided to publish the proceedings of the meeting as one of the volumes in the Santa Fe series. And so one of them and, uh, that was, uh, it was co-edited with Jerome Singer and I. Jerome Singer is a psychology professor at Yale who was also a member of the board of the Santa Fe Institute. And so, uh, uh, there was that collaboration. Gelman was one of our speakers. John Holland, who's also one of the moving forces at the Santa Fe Institute, was another one of our speakers. So there was that kind of, uh, not so much of a formal relationship, but those that informal overlap of people. So the Krasnow Institute, uh, Really became a defined entity with the publication of that that proceedings, which I understand still sells a few every year. And, and that sort of gave us the marching orders for, for what the Krasnow Institute was going to, to do. And so, uh, uh. The, the relationship after that has been, well, largely I go back and forth. I spend a good part of my summers at Santa Fe, and, uh, and Jim Old's, our director, also has some institutional attachment to people in Santa Fe. So there's that kind of, uh, personal relationships that that have sort of kept us as, as sister institutes as when we first got started, Ellen Goldberg was then the president of the Santa Fe Institute, and I set up an office for her in the Krasnow Institute here. So when she was in Washington, when she would come to deal with the various agencies, she had a, a formal, an institutional institutional home. So it was it was that kind of, uh, more, more informal and overlapping interests than than formal relationship. Have there been any other collaborative projects between the two institutes? Not formal projects? No. It's all been people interacting. To get more individual level. Right. Are there any plans to do anything in the future? Not that I know of. Okay. Um, maybe we'll switch now to talking a little bit about complexity. And with it being really the heart of the Santa Fe Institute. Um, and to your own personal experience, we were interested in finding out when you first became interested in complexity. Okay. It was that summer that we talked about when I was out at the Santa Fe Institute. I had never thought about complexity as a as a specific subject, although I had been, uh, working, uh, forever on, on biological systems, which are by their very nature complex and particular with the biochemical underpinnings of life, where you have hundreds and of compounds and thousands of proteins and so forth and so on. And it has an inherent complexity. And then when you get to ecology and evolution, you're into millions of species and all sorts of things like that. So biology before we actually called it complex, was inherently complex and we knew it. But when there got to be scientific methods and mathematical and computational methods designed to deal with complex systems, it was a matter of fitting those into into that framework. So how has the Santa Fe Institute been important to the study of complexity? I think most people sort of identify it as the home of complexity. It's where the where the general ideas first came together were meetings specifically to think about things as complex systems came together. And then those people went out and began to carry the message around the world. For the last few years, they've been having summer meetings in Beijing, and there have been meetings in Europe. And I believe a meeting is planned in India and another one in South Africa. So, so there's been, uh, but but a lot of this has, has come from people who are initially at the institute or who had attended meetings at the institute and then went back, for instance, a group who were originally associated with the institute, who came from the University of Michigan, have established a a I don't know what it's a department or division of some kind for the study of complexity in Ann Arbor. And there have been a number of number of examples like that where people began. Got their contact and got to think about the concept of complexity and. Oh, and then, yeah, I should tell you, in the mid 1990s, uh, uh, a journal was formed called complexity. And uh, I was the first editor of that. Uh, and that again, uh, is published by John Wiley. But it was an attempt to put together a place where where general articles on this subject could be published. And I edited it up until about two 2000, roughly when Peter Schuster took over as editor. He's a professor from the University of Vienna, and he now edits that journal. So that that, again, was an identification of the Santa Fe Institute with complexity through the journal. Are there any other sister institutions? Um, you said that the Krasno and Santa Fe have this informal relationship. Are there any other? Well, uh, with respect to Krasno, we sort of have that kind of relation with the Woods Hole Marine Biology Laboratory because their Uh, summer programs up there that some of our people come to. Uh, Jim Olds, who's our director, actually edits their journal. So again, that's that. But again, that's not a a formal relationship either. These, uh, to tell you the truth, these informal ones work much better. The so we, we relate to principally to those two. Mhm. Do you have any plans to visit Santa Fe. I go out I'll be there June and July this year. Mhm. Last year I was there June, July and May, June and July. Mhm. Uh I, I my plans are to spend that time there because that's when this collaborative group that I work with we, we work together every day on that there. Mhm. Mhm. Are there any other topics that you think we should address? Yeah. Well, I, I do think that there the two institutions are the most closely associated with and, and they're both rather different institutions. Uh, I don't know of any other institution quite like the Santa Fe Institute, which is so brought together people from all different disciplines. Uh, and that's including the that's including both the faculty and the researchers who come there and also the board of trustees who come from various places. The one of the members of the board of trustees is a man named Stewart Brand, who is the man who was the founder and editor of the Whole Earth Catalog. And then he later went on to go into, uh, uh, various computer businesses and of which he's been successful, and he's now a member of the board of trustees. There's been biography of him has come out recently called From Counterculture to Cyberculture. And so it's people like that, uh, the, uh, who you meet when you go out. So it's not only as you I mean, you meet when you go there for the board of Trustees meeting. But it's not only the the staff and the scientists. It's the board of trustees. The the president of the board of trustees now is a man named, uh, Bill Miller, who's from Baltimore, who for 15 years has run a Legg Mason has run a mutual fund which beat the Standard and Poor's for 15 years. And it's so there's this really interesting, uh, bringing together people at every level. And uh, the and even the, the people who come there as students and fellows for, for, for the summer. And, uh, so last year I was there, I met there was this interesting young man from China who was studying ecology, and there was this young lady from Romania who got studying epidemiology. And when she was there, and these were people who came as, as as students. It's not, uh. It's hard to put it in a kind of a formal documents, but but it's that it's that combination of having brought people together at every level that I think has made it work. And literally, literally every level from from high school students to corporate giants. And I mean, I haven't been connected with anything else that has had that character. And then, uh, in a sense, the Krasnow Institute is growing in that direction. Although being part of a university, it doesn't have quite the flexibility of doing all the kinds of things you can do at the Santa Fe Institute because they have to fit into a larger, larger institutional role. But but again, here we like to bring together people from all kinds of aspects of, of, of the mind, the brain and complex systems to, to come together and, and hopefully to solve some problems. Do you have any follow ups? No, I think it was. Yeah. Excellent. And this but. Well thank you very much. Thank you very much. Okay. Thank. You.

lines.line: # Introduction to the Interview and Background of Santa Fe Institute

> The interview begins with an introduction of Dr. Harold Morowitz, a professor at George Mason University, who discusses his involvement with the Santa Fe Institute. The speaker describes how he first learned about the institute in 1987 while seeking a venue for a pioneering workshop on computers and biology. This initial contact led to a long-term association with the institute, which was just getting established at the time.

metadata.title: Introduction to the Interview and Background of Santa Fe Institute
metadata.synopsis: The interview begins with an introduction of Dr. Harold Morowitz, a professor at George Mason University, who discusses his involvement with the Santa Fe Institute. The speaker describes how he first learned about the institute in 1987 while seeking a venue for a pioneering workshop on computers and biology. This initial contact led to a long-term association with the institute, which was just getting established at the time.

lines.line: # Early Workshops and the Role of Santa Fe Institute

> The speaker recounts his efforts in organizing one of the first workshops on computers and biology, highlighting the challenges of finding a suitable venue with affordable overhead costs. The Santa Fe Institute, being newly established, offered a viable option that facilitated the successful execution of the workshop, which was held at Saint John's College under the institute's auspices.

metadata.title: Early Workshops and the Role of Santa Fe Institute
metadata.synopsis: The speaker recounts his efforts in organizing one of the first workshops on computers and biology, highlighting the challenges of finding a suitable venue with affordable overhead costs. The Santa Fe Institute, being newly established, offered a viable option that facilitated the successful execution of the workshop, which was held at Saint John's College under the institute's auspices.

lines.line: # Development of Bioinformatics and Collaborative Projects

> The speaker elaborates on the significant outcomes of the early workshops, particularly how they fostered enthusiasm and collaboration among participants, leading to the development of the field of bioinformatics in the United States. Notable attendees of these workshops went on to become key figures in the field, contributing to its growth and the establishment of foundational concepts and practices.

lines.line: # The Growth and Expansion of Santa Fe Institute

> The speaker discusses the physical and academic expansion of the Santa Fe Institute over the years, from its initial setup in a rented convent to its current location in a large property that was previously owned by a notable figure. This growth reflects the institute's increasing influence and the broadening of its academic pursuits, which now include a diverse range of complex systems studies.

metadata.title: The Growth and Expansion of Santa Fe Institute

This growth reflects the institute's increasing influence and the broadening of its academic pursuits, which now include a diverse range of complex systems studies.

lines.line: # Relationship and Collaborations with Krasnow Institute

> The speaker details the informal yet significant relationship between the Santa Fe Institute and the Krasnow Institute, emphasizing collaborative projects and shared academic events. This relationship has been marked by mutual interests in complex systems and has facilitated various joint activities, including conferences and the sharing of resources and expertise between the two institutes.

metadata.title: Relationship and Collaborations with Krasnow Institute
metadata.synopsis: The speaker details the informal yet significant relationship between the Santa Fe Institute and the Krasnow Institute, emphasizing collaborative projects and shared academic events. This relationship has been marked by mutual interests in complex systems and has facilitated various joint activities, including conferences and the sharing of resources and expertise between the two institutes.

lines.line: # Personal Involvement and Interest in Complexity

> The speaker reflects on his personal journey into the study of complexity, which began during his time at the Santa Fe Institute. His work on biological systems naturally transitioned into the study of complexity due to the inherent complexity of biological processes. This interest has led to significant collaborations and contributions to the field, particularly in understanding the theoretical underpinnings of complex systems.

lines.line: > The speaker discusses his upcoming plans to visit the Santa Fe Institute and reflects on the unique nature of the institute. He highlights the diverse and interdisciplinary environment of the institute, which brings together individuals from various fields and levels of expertise, from students to corporate leaders. This unique setup fosters a rich environment for innovation and collaboration across different disciplines.

metadata.title: Future Plans and Concluding Thoughts
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses his upcoming plans to visit the Santa Fe Institute and reflects on the unique nature of the institute. He highlights the diverse and interdisciplinary environment of the institute, which brings together individuals from various fields and levels of expertise, from students to corporate leaders. This unique setup fosters a rich environment for innovation and collaboration across different disciplines.

children.text: # Introduction to the Interview and Background of Santa Fe Institute

> The interview begins with an introduction of Dr. Harold Morowitz, a professor at George Mason University, who discusses his involvement with the Santa Fe Institute. The speaker describes how he first learned about the institute in 1987 while seeking a venue for a pioneering workshop on computers and biology. This initial contact led to a long-term association with the institute, which was just getting established at the time.
# Early Workshops and the Role of Santa Fe Institute

> The speaker recounts his efforts in organizing one of the first workshops on computers and biology, highlighting the challenges of finding a suitable venue with affordable overhead costs. The Santa Fe Institute, being newly established, offered a viable option that facilitated the successful execution of the workshop, which was held at Saint John's College under the institute's auspices.
# Development of Bioinformatics and Collaborative Projects

> The speaker elaborates on the significant outcomes of the early workshops, particularly how they fostered enthusiasm and collaboration among participants, leading to the development of the field of bioinformatics in the United States. Notable attendees of these workshops went on to become key figures in the field, contributing to its growth and the establishment of foundational concepts and practices.
# The Growth and Expansion of Santa Fe Institute

> The speaker discusses the physical and academic expansion of the Santa Fe Institute over the years, from its initial setup in a rented convent to its current location in a large property that was previously owned by a notable figure. This growth reflects the institute's increasing influence and the broadening of its academic pursuits, which now include a diverse range of complex systems studies.
# Relationship and Collaborations with Krasnow Institute

> The speaker details the informal yet significant relationship between the Santa Fe Institute and the Krasnow Institute, emphasizing collaborative projects and shared academic events. This relationship has been marked by mutual interests in complex systems and has facilitated various joint activities, including conferences and the sharing of resources and expertise between the two institutes.

His work on biological systems naturally transitioned into the study of complexity due to the inherent complexity of biological processes. > The speaker discusses his upcoming plans to visit the Santa Fe Institute and reflects on the unique nature of the institute. He highlights the diverse and interdisciplinary environment of the institute, which brings together individuals from various fields and levels of expertise, from students to corporate leaders. This unique setup fosters a rich environment for innovation and collaboration across different disciplines.
